awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Establishing a Child Speech Fluency Database
awd_abstract_narration:
How children learn to produce speech smoothly without stops, restarts, errors, or omissions (known as speech fluency), has received little research attention.  Some children who exhibit fluency difficulties, such as later-talking and bilingual children, are misdiagnosed with speech disorders such as stuttering as a result. However different fluency issues require different types of speech or language therapy.  A better understanding of typical fluency development and of different types of fluency problems can inform the neural, linguistic and motor coordination demands that underlie speech fluency.  The goal of the current project is to develop a comprehensive database archive of audio and video recordings of child speech and their corresponding transcripts that can be used for both basic and clinical research on the development of speech fluency in children.   

This project examines fluency development during the preschool years in typical, late-talking, and bilingual children, by using existing data contributed to the CHILDES Project (www.childes.psy.cmu.edu), an open access archive of children's speech samples. Additional corpora from late-talking and bilingual children will also be included to establish a new, more comprehensive "Fluency Bank" archive.  All corpora will be reformatted to validate and revise transcripts, index speech rate, characterize disfluencies, and code speech for grammatical features.  Automatic and semi-automatic approaches will be used to link audio recordings and transcripts. The resulting Fluency Bank will become an important and unique research resource for those interested in fluency development in both typically and atypically developing children.

por.por_cntn:
How children learn to speak fluently in so few years is still a mystery. Additionally, why some succeed and others develop fluency disorders such as stuttering is unknown. Finally, why disfluency seen in typical children and second language learners, and children who stutter seems qualitatively different has not been well-explored in past research. Finally, many older adults become disfluent. It is possible that analysis of their speech may identify different reasons for their increasing speech difficulty.

This project (co-sponsored by the National Institutes on Deafness and other Communication Disorders (NIDCD)) constructed a multi-media, open access repository of research data (FluencyBank (fluency.talkbank.org), a subproject of the international TalkBank initiative). The goal of such repositories is to encourage researchers to share data and to use existing data to answer research questions, rather than depend solely on new data collection each time a research hypothesis requires testing. The primary focus of FluencyBank has been the development of spoken language fluency over childhood, in typical and disordered children, as well as those growing up bilingual. It has also conducted re-analysis of data from adults who began experiencing significant fluency difficulty later in life, from a companion archive (AphasiaBank).

Since the grant was awarded, FluencyBank has processed and posted 13 large datasets from completed projects that were previous recipients of federal funding. These included data from over 400 speakers, totaling 2,979 transcripts and 95 GB of media, plus additional resources for use by university instructors in teaching speech development and disorders. We also developed uniform rules for coding fluency in spoken language transcripts that can be shared across languages and alphabets. The FluencyBank database now includes data from speakers of English, Dutch, German and French, from typical child/adult/elderly speakers. It also includes data from clinical populations, such as people who stutter (PWS), children with language delay, and children and adolescents with Down Syndrome. We also developed and distributed free computer software to enable users to search and examine the spoken language transcripts on multiple levels of analysis.

Since its founding, FluencyBank data have now been used in research for automatic diagnosis of speech impairment. It is also being used in projects to make automatic speech recognition (e.g., Alexa, Google) more accessible by speakers with disabilities, a clear translational benefit of archival research data.

Educational impacts of FluencyBank are growing daily. To guide instruction in Communication Sciences and Disorders, we collected and posted a set of 46 open-access video interviews from adults and children with fluency disorders using a standard elicitation protocol. These materials have been adopted by large numbers of University teaching programs world-wide. FluencyBank research, software and teaching videos feature prominently in three frequently utilized texts on the nature of stuttering. A contributed chapter on use of FluencyBank utilities appears in a recent major text on speech/language assessment. FluencyBank has already been identified as the data-sharing vehicle for all major federal grants in fluency/fluency disorders, as well as clinical trials of pharmacological agents used in stuttering treatment.

FluencyBank has made major contributions internationally with 5 publications and 15 presentations at national/international meetings. Two of these publications have identified new predictors of recovery from childhood stuttering; another helped distinguish disfluency that accompanies stroke from that which characterizes one form of dementia. Since 2016, FluencyBank has held ten workshops around the U.S. and worldwide (Great Britain, the Netherlands, Japan) to train researchers who work in spoken language development how to use FluencyBank tools and resources.
